results.title: The Best and Worst Moments of the 2021 Oscars
results.abstract: In between a cinematic entrance and a letdown of an ending, there were breakthroughs, heartbreaks and a wolf howl. It was a strange night.

results.title: ‘Nomadland’ Makes History, and Anthony Hopkins, in Upset, Wins Best Actor
results.abstract: Chloé Zhao’s film about the damaged American dream won best picture, best director and best actress. The late Chadwick Boseman, who was considered the frontrunner for best actor, was beat out by Hopkins.
results.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling
org_facet: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences

results.title: The Covid-19 Oscars: Not Masked but Still Muffled
results.abstract: A stripped-down ceremony stripped out too much of what makes the show, for better or worse, worth watching.

results.title: Anthony Hopkins Accepts Oscar, Paying Tribute to Chadwick Boseman
results.abstract: “At 83 years of age I did not expect to get this award,” Hopkins said of his best actor win in a video posted early on Monday morning.

multimedia.caption: Anthony Hopkins won the award for best actor at the Oscars for his role in “The Father” — and, hours later, he delivered an acceptance speech in a video from Wales.

results.title: China Censors Chloé Zhao’s Oscar Win, but Fans Find Ways to Rejoice
results.abstract: On social media, the director’s fans blurred out her name and turned images on their sides to evade the censors. “People should be celebrating,” one writer said.
results.byline: By Amy Qin and Amy Chang Chien

results.title: And the Oscar Goes to … a Film From a Video Game

results.title: Yuh-Jung Youn becomes the first Korean woman in Oscar history to win best supporting actress.
results.abstract: “How can I win over Glenn Close?” Youn said while accepting the award for her role in “Minari.” “Tonight, I have just a little bit luck, I think, maybe.”

results.title: Chloé Zhao becomes the first woman of color to win best director.
results.abstract: The filmmaker behind “Nomadland” has been winning all season long and is already at work on her next project, the superhero team-up “Eternals.”

results.title: Mia Neal and Jamika Wilson are the first Black women to win for hair and makeup.

results.title: Behind ‘Strange Fruit,’ Billie Holiday’s Anti-Lynching Anthem
results.abstract: It helped make Holiday a star, but it was written by Abel Meeropol, a teacher in the Bronx. An Oscar nomination and a year of protests against racism have kept it in the conversation.
des_facet: The United States vs Billie Holiday (Movie)

results.title: Quick, Here’s All You Need to Know About the Oscars
results.abstract: Theaters were shut but the ceremony is still happening? Yep! In a podcast, our awards experts catch you up.

results.title: How ‘Rocks’ Made Stars of Its Schoolgirl Cast
results.abstract: By casting first-time actors, the film tells a story rarely seen onscreen: what growing up is like for British women of color.

multimedia.caption: Clockwise from top: Ruby Stokes, Kosar Ali, Bukky Bakray, Anastasia Dymitrow, Tawheda Begum and Afi Okaidja. The casting team for “Rocks” saw 1,300 girls to find actors to play the film’s East London teenagers.

Clockwise from top: Ruby Stokes, Kosar Ali, Bukky Bakray, Anastasia Dymitrow, Tawheda Begum and Afi Okaidja. The casting team for “Rocks” saw 1,300 girls to find actors to play the film’s East London teenagers.

Clockwise from top: Ruby Stokes, Kosar Ali, Bukky Bakray, Anastasia Dymitrow, Tawheda Begum and Afi Okaidja. The casting team for “Rocks” saw 1,300 girls to find actors to play the film’s East London teenagers.

Clockwise from top: Ruby Stokes, Kosar Ali, Bukky Bakray, Anastasia Dymitrow, Tawheda Begum and Afi Okaidja. The casting team for “Rocks” saw 1,300 girls to find actors to play the film’s East London teenagers.

Clockwise from top: Ruby Stokes, Kosar Ali, Bukky Bakray, Anastasia Dymitrow, Tawheda Begum and Afi Okaidja. The casting team for “Rocks” saw 1,300 girls to find actors to play the film’s East London teenagers.
